headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the EQT Corporation Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Patrick Kane, Chief Investor Relations Officer. Ple
componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the EQT Corporation Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Patrick Kane, Chief Investor Relations Officer. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jennifer. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for participating in the EQT Corporation's Conference Call. With me today are David Porges, President and Chief Executive Officer; Phil Conti, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Randy
componenttext:
Thanks, Jennifer. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for participating in the EQT Corporation's Conference Call. With me today are David Porges, President and Chief Executive Officer; Phil Conti, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Randy Crawford, Senior Vice President and President of Midstream Commercial; and Steve Schlotterbeck, Executive Vice President and President of Exploration & Production.
This call will be replayed for a 7-day period beginning at approximately 1:30 P.M. today. The telephone number for the replay is (719) 457-0820.
The confirmation code is 8682699. The call will also be replayed for 7 days on our website. 
To remind you, the results of the EQT Midstream Partners, ticker EQM; and EQGP Holdings, ticker EQGP, are consolidated in EQT's results. Earlier this morning, there was a separate joint press release issued by EQM and EQGP. The partnerships conference call is at 11:30 AM today, which requires that we take the last question at 11:20. The dial-in number for that call is (913) 312-9034. The confirmation code is 2157781.
In just a moment, Phil will summarize EQT's results. Next, Steve will have a brief Utica update. Finally, Dave will provide preliminary thoughts on EQT's 2016 capital budget. Following the prepared remarks, Dave, Phil, Randy and Steve will be available to answer your questions.
I'd like to remind you that today's call may contain forward-looking statements. You can find factors that could cause the company's actual results to differ materially from these forward-looking statements listed in today's press release and under risk factors in EQT's Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2014, as updated by any subsequent Form 10-Qs, which are on file at the SEC and available on our website.
Today's call may also contain certain non-GAAP financial measures. Please refer to this morning's press release for important disclosures regarding such financial measures, including reconciliations to the most comparable GAAP financial measures.
Before turning the call over to Phil, I will walk you through one of the non-GAAP reconciliations that caused some confusion last quarter, specifically, Production adjusted net operating revenue presented on Page 7 of today's release. This number is used as the basis for calculating our average realized sales price as presented on the price reconciliation including -- included in this morning's release. The average realized price is calculated by dividing the adjusted net operating revenue by total sales volumes.
There is a non-capitalization in the release that I will briefly explain. We are making 2 adjustments to EQT Production total operating revenues as reported on the segment page in order to provide you with operating revenues excluding the noncash impact of derivatives and the net of transportation and processing costs. 
With respect to derivatives, adjustments for nontax derivative activity have been a subject of SEC comments over the past couple of years. As a result, in accordance with what appears to be the SEC's preference in this area, we adjust of noncash activity in 3 steps. First, we backout all gains and losses on derivatives [indiscernible] made this as hedges that were included in revenues during the period, which is the mark-to-market impact, which was 150 -- $160.5 million this quarter. Two, we add back the actual cash received, $33.2 million and deduct the premiums paid for derivatives that settled during the quarter, which was $1 million, which leaves us with just the actual cash received net of any premiums made in our adjusted revenue number.
So final adjustment on our non-GAAP reconciliations reduces the total operating revenues by $64.7 million of cost reported as expense on EQT Production segment page for transportation and processing. This provides a realized price net of processing cost, which is consistent with our historic presentation.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Phil Conti.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Pat, and good morning, everyone. As you read in the press release this morning, EQT announced the third quarter 2015 adjusted loss of $0.33 per diluted share, which represents an $0.83 per share decrease from adjusted EPS in the third quarter of '
componenttext:
Thanks, Pat, and good morning, everyone. As you read in the press release this morning, EQT announced the third quarter 2015 adjusted loss of $0.33 per diluted share, which represents an $0.83 per share decrease from adjusted EPS in the third quarter of '14.
Adjusted operating cash flow was $156.3 million in the quarter or 46% lower than the third quarter of 2014. Results for the quarter were negatively impacted by lower commodity prices. Due to lower prices since last quarter, we also recorded a significant noncash gain on hedges of future production of $128.3 million during the quarter and that was some of the stuff that Pat just talked and that's excluded from in the adjusted earnings and cash flow.
If I could take a look at our continuing and recently activities at EQGP. On October 20, [ph] 2015, EQGP announced that cash distribution to its unit holders of $0.104 per unit for the third quarter of '15 or a 13% increase over the equivalent full quarter distribution in the second quarter.
The third quarter distribution position represents $24.9 million in payments, which EQGP will receive on November 23. These quarterly payments will continue to grow as distributions on EQGP grow and highlight the value of EQGP to EQT. 
The operational results were fairly straightforward in the third quarter, so I'll move right into the segment results and I will be brief.
First, EQT Production continued to grow production sales volume by 27% compared to the third quarter of 2014. However, revenues from that growth were more than offset by the lower commodity prices negatively impacting results in the third quarter. The average realized price at EQT Production was $1.21 per Mcf equivalent, a 55% decrease from $2.69 per Mcf equivalent last year, which led to adjusted operating revenues for the quarter of $188.5 million or $142.5 million lower than last year's third quarter.
There were many factors that led to the lower price, but lower NYMEX and liquids prices versus last year were the primary drivers. You will find the detailed components of the price differences in the tables in this morning's release.
Adjusted operating loss at EQT Production was $72 million excluding the noncash gain on hedges or $128.3 million that I just mentioned. That compared to adjusted operating income of $107.9 million in the third quarter of '14, and that was also excluding the noncash gain on hedges.
Total operating expenses at EQT Production was $325.2 million or [indiscernible] higher compared to the third quarter 2014. DD&A was $30.2 million higher. Transportation and processing expense was about $16 million higher. Exploration expense was $4.6 million higher. And ROE, excluding production taxes, was about $1.6 million higher. All consistent with the rolling growth. Production tax decreased by $3 million due to lower commodity prices in the period.
SG&A expense excluding $3.5 million in [indiscernible] was about $500,000 higher. 
Midstream results. Here, the operating income was up 21%, and the increase is consistent with the growth of gathered volumes and increased capacity-based transmission charges. Gathering revenues increased 23 -- 23% to $125.9 million in the third quarter of '15 primarily due to a 24% increase in gathered volumes.
Transmission revenues for the third quarter 2015 increased by $6.9 million or 12% driven by additional firm contracted capacity added over the past year. 
Operating expenses at Midstream for the third quarter of $82.2 million were about $9.4 million higher than last year, consistent with the growth in the Midstream business. 
And just to conclude with a brief note on liquidity, EQT did have $1.7 million of cash on hand at quarter end, not including the cash at EQM and EQGP as well as forward [indiscernible] under EQT's $1.5 billion credit facility. So we remain in a strong liquidity position to accomplish our goals for the foreseeable future.
Our current estimate of 2015 EQT operating cash flow is $900 million adjusted to exclude the noncontrolling interest portion of EQM and EQGP's cash flow. 
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Steve.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Phil. Today, I'll provide you with an update on our [indiscernible] program. As discussed on the last call, we completed our first EQT Utica well in July, the 591330 [ph] . To remind you, the well's initial 24-hour flow was 72.9 million cubic f
componenttext:
Thank you, Phil. Today, I'll provide you with an update on our [indiscernible] program. As discussed on the last call, we completed our first EQT Utica well in July, the 591330 [ph] . To remind you, the well's initial 24-hour flow was 72.9 million cubic feet with an average [indiscernible] pressure of 8,641 PSI. We've been boring this well directly into the pipeline at a restricted rate of about 30 million cubic feet per day. Except for the 7 days required to install the wellhead equipment, the only sales have been steady at this rate. Casing pressure has been declining at an average of 40 PSI per day. As of yesterday, sales volumes were 30.4 million cubic feet per day and the casing pressure was 6,320 PSI.
Cumulative production from this well has totaled at 2.6 Bcf in the first 86 days of production. Our expectation is that the daily production rate will not decline until the well pressure declines through the pipeline pressure, which is 500 PSI. Based on an extrapolation of the current pressure decline rate, we estimate that we pressure after approximately 8 months of production, which will be in the late March, 2016. The cumulative production at that time would be approximately 7.4 Bcf. 
At that point, we had a wide range of possible decline curves as we do not have any analogous decline data to rely on. Our current reservoir model suggests an ultimate expected recovery for this well in the range between 13.9 Bcf and 18.8 Bcf or a range of 4.3 to 5.9 Bcf per thousand foot of lateral. 
[indiscernible] the lowest of our range and assuming the high end of our cost per well target of between $12.5 million and $14 million per well, we estimate returns of a $2 wellhead gas price to be north of 20% for a 5,400-foot lateral well.
Since the last call, we've spent 2 additional Utica wells. In August, we spread a second well, with number 593066, which is located approximately 5 miles northeast of the well. We're currently at a depth of 12,200 feet and install the intermediate casing.
We're just beginning to draw the curve on this well and expect this well to be in line before the end of the year.
The third well is spread it September in Wetzel County, West Virginia, the big 190 well and is located approximately 30 miles southwest of the well. We reached TD as a deep intermediate hole. We topped old rig is to move up the well and well is secured or waiting to be great to run the intermediate casing. The rest of the drill will be completed in the Blue County rig is finished with the well and that rig is moved to West Virginia later this year.
We are making good progress on cost reductions for these wells, specifically at the current depth of the well, where we spent approximately 22% less than we did on these well at the same point. 
As I previously noted, we expect it to take several wells for us to achieve our cost target for these wells of between $12.5 million and $14 million. We are pleased with our progress so far and remain confident that we will achieve our targeted cost. We will continue to well data from the well in our analyst presentation periodically and we'll update you on the progress of the latest 2 wells [indiscernible] 
I'll now turn the call over to David Porges for [indiscernible] capital budget.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve, and good morning, everyone. Today, the topic of my prepared remarks, as Steve mentioned, is our preliminary thinking regarding EQT's 2016 capital budget. We met with our board last week to discuss our long-term strategy as we do every Oc
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve, and good morning, everyone. Today, the topic of my prepared remarks, as Steve mentioned, is our preliminary thinking regarding EQT's 2016 capital budget. We met with our board last week to discuss our long-term strategy as we do every October. We then meets in early December to approve the upcoming year's operating plan and capital budget. 
A key aspect of the discussion in the last week's meeting was the impact of the emerging deep Utica play on EQT's strategy. There have been fewer than 10 wells drilled and completed in the Deep Utica around our so it is still too early to be confident that the play would be economic, but the early results are certainly encouraging.
Specifically, if the Utica does work, which for us means that the returns are better than returns from the core Marcellus, we will certainly add significant resource potential to our inventory.  However, the current price in natural gas will likely be lower in that scenario and at the Utica is less economic. As a result, some of our other inventory to acquire high prices to make economic returns would be deferred possibly for many years. So while those of us, certainly including EQT, who has significant positions in the core of the Deep Utica would be the winners, if you will. The cannibalization of other opportunities will affect everyone, including those of us who will net-net be much better off if the Deep Utica play does work economically. Given this potential for lower long-term gas prices, we do not think it prudent to invest much money in wells since all-in after tax returns exceed our investment hurdle rates by only a relatively small amount. As a result, we are suspending drilling in those areas such as Central Pennsylvania and our Upper Devonian play that are outside the core.
This decision will affect our 2016 capital plan, though we are just starting to develop the specifics of the 2016 drilling program that forms the core of the plan. The focus in 2016 will be on this more narrowly drawn notion of what the core Marcellus would be assuming the deep Utica play works.
We will also pursue the Deep Utica play with the goal of determining economics, size of resource and midstream needs and are lowering the cost per well to our target range. Our initial thoughts are a 10 to 15 well Deep Utica program in 2016 with flexibility to shift capital between Marcellus and Utica as warranted based on our progress. 
Our pulmonary estimate for production volume growth in 2016 versus 2015 is 15% to 20%, which we will refine when we announce our formal development plan in early December. If we turn in line our fourth quarter wells in late December, as contemplated in our fourth quarter guidance, 2016 growth would likely be near the upper end of that range as those wells will contribute little, if anything, to volumes until early 2016.
Obviously, this overall approach will result in a 2016 capital budget, absent any acquisitions, that is a fair bit lower than 2015 and would result in continuing [indiscernible] of cash on hand as of in 2016, but we will provide specifics in December.
Another strategic implication of an economic Deep Utica play is a significant opportunity for EQM. A year ago, it would be hard to imagine -- would've been hard to imagine a more prolific play than the Marcellus. EQM has already announced a $3 billion backlog of midstream projects to serve the Marcellus play. [indiscernible] our current backlog continues to make sense if the Deep Utica proves economic as it either supports core Marcellus or take away projects that are needed regardless of the source raw for the natural gas.
However, if the Deep Utica works, it is likely to be larger than the Marcellus over time. The magnitude of incremental take away and gathering pipeline such a play with support is significant, even net of the previously mentioned reduction to Marcellus development that would occur in the scenario.
As we think about the EQT corporate structure, we are not likely to make any major decisions to change the current integrated model until we do understand the scope of the potential Deep Utica development program. We have reached much value in recent years from having the 2 businesses together and there is the potential that both companies would continue to benefit from these synergies into the dawn of the Utica era.
Finally, the Deep Utica potential has also affected our thoughts around acreage acquisitions. Given our view that our existing acreage sits on what is expected to be the core of the core in Deep Utica, we are focusing our interest -- our area of interest even more tightly on acreage that is in our core Marcellus and potentially core Deep Utica area.
As you can probably deduce from the lack of significant transaction announcements, the spread continues to be wide. We are a patient company and believe that there will be acreage available at fair prices eventually, but the definition of fair has to contemplate the potential that the Deep Utica works.
We do not think that bodes well for the price of acreage concentrating in anything but the core Marcellus and core Utica. This narrowly focus also suggests that smaller asset deals are much more likely than larger corporate deals. However, as we've stated previously, we are comfortable maintaining our industry-leading balance sheet even as we look for opportunities to create value.
In conclusion, EQT is committed to increasing the value of your shares and we look forward to continuing to execute on our commitment to our shareholders and appreciate your continued support. With that, I'll turn the call back over to Pat Kane.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Dave, on the M&A, your thoughts and I would agree on the strong obviously position you have in that Deep Utica. Are you and Steve thinking more bolt-on in that area? Are there other so big packages you see, anything else you can add about what you're kind
componenttext: Dave, on the M&A, your thoughts and I would agree on the strong obviously position you have in that Deep Utica. Are you and Steve thinking more bolt-on in that area? Are there other so big packages you see, anything else you can add about what you're kind of look in that regard to M&A in that area?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Steve has been closer to that. I would let him answer that question.
componenttext: Steve has been closer to that. I would let him answer that question.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Neal. Our primary focus in terms of looking at acquisitions is really focused on a pretty narrow core area and we'll be updating our investor presentation later today and you'll see a map that shows kind of the area most of interest to us where we w
componenttext: Sure, Neal. Our primary focus in terms of looking at acquisitions is really focused on a pretty narrow core area and we'll be updating our investor presentation later today and you'll see a map that shows kind of the area most of interest to us where we will be focusing our development program as well as any M&A activity that we'd be interested in. So right now, it seems like there's people who are interested in selling assets. So far, the prices are still a bit high. But as Dave said, we plan on being patient in waiting for what we would consider fair prices before we transact.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, the 10 to 15 wells you mentioned, Steve, in the Deep Utica, your thoughts, how far North, I mean, you've got obviously some interesting acreage all the way up in the Allegheny, given how successful obviously their well all cleared up in th
componenttext: Okay. And then, the 10 to 15 wells you mentioned, Steve, in the Deep Utica, your thoughts, how far North, I mean, you've got obviously some interesting acreage all the way up in the Allegheny, given how successful obviously their well all cleared up in the West Norlin. Just your thoughts on and any ideas you can give us on those 10 to 15 well. Will most of those be focused down around that Greene County area? Or will you take them all the way up to potentially north as Allegheny?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we haven't spotted all of those 10 to 15, so it will depend on the results we see. But I would say, certainly the Southern Allegheny County where we have a pretty significant position and high expectations for the Utica. Maybe up into the Northern A
componenttext: Well, we haven't spotted all of those 10 to 15, so it will depend on the results we see. But I would say, certainly the Southern Allegheny County where we have a pretty significant position and high expectations for the Utica. Maybe up into the Northern Allegheny, but more likely it will be for us, Southwestern Armstrong where we have an acreage position. I think our view would probably be others define that area. Part of the reason would be more limited takeaway capacity up there. So probably not going to be in a big hurry to drill some of these monster wells up there. Probably more focus from Southern Allegheny, down into Southern Wetzel and maybe a bit over into far Western Marion County.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just the last question, just on take away for the dry gas. Dave, at one-time, David, you thought I think you have commented really the only limitation might be just take away as far and given how successful these wells and how economic th
componenttext: Got it. And then just the last question, just on take away for the dry gas. Dave, at one-time, David, you thought I think you have commented really the only limitation might be just take away as far and given how successful these wells and how economic these wells look. If you and Steve can talk about, is that -- again, does that have limitations to how many wells you drill next year? Or by some point next year, you'll have ample Utica take away?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think these -- if the early results continue to show up, like we see things in some of those early results in future wells, I think we'll probably going to be looking at take away limitations for a world. I mean, I think these wells can probably support
componenttext: I think these -- if the early results continue to show up, like we see things in some of those early results in future wells, I think we'll probably going to be looking at take away limitations for a world. I mean, I think these wells can probably support volumes at the midstream wasn't really designed for. It's -- I mean we would probably and read the spoke to this but it's going to take a little while probably to figure out what the right midstream configuration is for the Deep Utica. Randy, do you have any thoughts on that?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I concur. Obviously, we've been trying to stay up in front of the Marcellus and we've worked at our connector that's coming around. But I would also say we're looking at the systems and how we can leverage that and the infrastructure that we have in E
componenttext: No, I concur. Obviously, we've been trying to stay up in front of the Marcellus and we've worked at our connector that's coming around. But I would also say we're looking at the systems and how we can leverage that and the infrastructure that we have in Equitrans. So I think we're best positioned to move a bit of the product, but certainly, these wells are quite exciting. And so that will take a lot of additional infrastructure as we develop the play.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, certainly the cost per unit is going to be considerably less than [indiscernible] Marcellus because of the higher volumes. And frankly, the more concentrated nature of it. I mean, it's not just higher volumes. It's that you can get it from a tighter
componenttext: Well, certainly the cost per unit is going to be considerably less than [indiscernible] Marcellus because of the higher volumes. And frankly, the more concentrated nature of it. I mean, it's not just higher volumes. It's that you can get it from a tighter area. That's a much better answer from the perspective of unit gathering compression costs. I said the compression costs early on is going to probably be a round number.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes.
componenttext: Yes, yes.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. And we'll go next to Phillip Jungwirth from BMO.
componenttext: Thank you. And we'll go next to Phillip Jungwirth from BMO.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions on Utica well cost. First, wondering if you could provide us with the for the second Greene County and first Wetzel County Utica wells. And then second, your targeted well cost supply about 2,500 per foot, which I know is compares to
componenttext: A couple of questions on Utica well cost. First, wondering if you could provide us with the for the second Greene County and first Wetzel County Utica wells. And then second, your targeted well cost supply about 2,500 per foot, which I know is compares to some of the smaller peers over in County who are recording 1,200 to 1,500 per foot. Obviously, the Pennsylvania Utica is 13,000 being compared to 10,000, but do you think that deeper depth and higher pressures would account for all this difference? Or could there be further room to bring cost down as you progress your development?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Phil, this is Steve. I guess the regarding the AFPs, I don't have the exact numbers in front of me, but they're in the low $17 millions per well. That cost will be dependent on the open lateral length. So we have some flexibility about how long we end up
componenttext:
Phil, this is Steve. I guess the regarding the AFPs, I don't have the exact numbers in front of me, but they're in the low $17 millions per well. That cost will be dependent on the open lateral length. So we have some flexibility about how long we end up drilling these. So I wouldn't put a whole lot of weight on those numbers but a significant decrease from the actual costs from our first well, which was around $30 [ph] million. And the second part of your question, remind me again?
or the cost per foot? I think our view is when we sit down and do a bottoms up analysis of what we think it should cost to drill these wells once you work through all of the problems and give the nonproductive time down to a minimum, that's where we come up with that $12.5 million. So I think, at current service costs, never say never. But we don't see a path to being significantly less than that for these wells. And I think the $14 million gives us some room to have a few unexpected problems that maybe we wouldn't normally have on Marcellus wells, which is why we're quoting a range right now. But our hope is to get to the bottom end of that range but very confident we will get within the top end.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. It looks like based on the EUR map that the implied FND is already pretty comparable to what you're seeing in Marcellus. Second question is, on the last call, you had mentioned how EQM is now more of an organic growth story. But with the narr
componenttext: Okay, great. It looks like based on the EUR map that the implied FND is already pretty comparable to what you're seeing in Marcellus. Second question is, on the last call, you had mentioned how EQM is now more of an organic growth story. But with the narrowing of Marcellus development in 2016 [ph] and beyond, how will this impact future drop downs given the most of the gathering and transmission assets held by EQT appear to be outside of the core Southwest PA, Northwest Virginia areas?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we're still working through what we want to do with future crowds but a comment about what's most economic for EQM is independent of that. But we're -- EQM is not as you know into the high splits. And it's just more economical for an MLP to organica
componenttext: Well, we're still working through what we want to do with future crowds but a comment about what's most economic for EQM is independent of that. But we're -- EQM is not as you know into the high splits. And it's just more economical for an MLP to organically develop projects than to have to pay off as long as it can afford it, as long as it's got the coverage that allows it to where that appeared of time when it's got assets tied up in projects that aren't generating cash flow. So we will have to work through what happens with the remaining projects, et cetera, as we go through 2016. But my comments in the past about organic growth being the preference is just because of the way it works when you've got all of that cash flow going to the GP.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then historically, EQT is always prefunded. The following years, cash flow has been with asset sales or drop downs. Would this also be the intention in 2016? Or do you consider the $1.7 billion in cash on the balance sheet as having already ac
componenttext: Got it. And then historically, EQT is always prefunded. The following years, cash flow has been with asset sales or drop downs. Would this also be the intention in 2016? Or do you consider the $1.7 billion in cash on the balance sheet as having already accomplished that given the, I think, you've had mentioned that you still have cash as of year-end '16?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd basically say that we already accomplished that.
componenttext: Yes, I'd basically say that we already accomplished that.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Michael Hall from Mike and energy advisors.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Michael Hall from Mike and energy advisors.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess I just wanted to touch a little bit on the backlog, kind of get your updated thoughts around how that progresses over time. Does that materially year-on-year continue to grow sequentially? Just trying to think through kind of what the strategy is
componenttext: I guess I just wanted to touch a little bit on the backlog, kind of get your updated thoughts around how that progresses over time. Does that materially year-on-year continue to grow sequentially? Just trying to think through kind of what the strategy is there when you think that this would ultimately be drawn down and how that's contemplated in the 2016 plan?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Michael, this is Steve. Yes, the backlog in terms of frac stages complete but not align grew a bit this quarter as you saw. Our expectation is that the fourth quarter will be a pretty big quarter for UTI. Most of those will be in the back half of the
componenttext: Yes, Michael, this is Steve. Yes, the backlog in terms of frac stages complete but not align grew a bit this quarter as you saw. Our expectation is that the fourth quarter will be a pretty big quarter for UTI. Most of those will be in the back half of the quarter. So it won't affect volumes in the quarter very much but should be coming on late. So I think you'll see a fairly significant drop back to more historic levels on the next call when we're talking about Q4.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And so, is it -- is there any thought process of continuing to draw drive that down even further in '16? Or does that move in [indiscernible] falling quarters kind of [indiscernible] you think that the replace year or kind of on a run rate?
componenttext: Okay. And so, is it -- is there any thought process of continuing to draw drive that down even further in '16? Or does that move in [indiscernible] falling quarters kind of [indiscernible] you think that the replace year or kind of on a run rate?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that will be more the typical run rate. If you look back over our history, if you go back 3 years or so, I think we've been giving these numbers. You'll see it's always very lumpy. The biggest driver behind that backlog is just the timing of the r
componenttext: I think that will be more the typical run rate. If you look back over our history, if you go back 3 years or so, I think we've been giving these numbers. You'll see it's always very lumpy. The biggest driver behind that backlog is just the timing of the rigs and the number of wells, the number of fracs per well for every pad we're on, so it tends to be very lumpy. Right now, we haven't been taking any heroic efforts to get wells online superfast, so that maybe drives the backlog a little bit this quarter. But again, you'll see by next quarter, we'll be back in the more closer to the mean over the past few years.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And any indications conditions around capital associated with that 2015 outlook?
componenttext: Okay. And any indications conditions around capital associated with that 2015 outlook?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Only that it would be less than 2015. I mean, it's a fallout of this narrowing focus. But I feel comfortable putting numbers out there when we're still, what, 6 weeks away from putting numbers in front of our own board. But if you're looking for direction
componenttext: Only that it would be less than 2015. I mean, it's a fallout of this narrowing focus. But I feel comfortable putting numbers out there when we're still, what, 6 weeks away from putting numbers in front of our own board. But if you're looking for directional, it would be clearly we're heading less than '15.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. Okay. And then I guess just wanted last question on my end, think about the fourth quarter little bit, I think you have kind of alluded to it in your comments about the backloaded nature of the completions. But the implications, backing of
componenttext: That's helpful. Okay. And then I guess just wanted last question on my end, think about the fourth quarter little bit, I think you have kind of alluded to it in your comments about the backloaded nature of the completions. But the implications, backing off the first 3 quarters of the year, kind of flat to down on the quarter. What are the, I guess, what are the sensitivities around that from an operational perspective? How should we think about what might put you on one end of the range or the other?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: The rate for the fourth quarter? I think we just stick with what Steve said, which is we're kind of aiming towards a lot of those payouts getting tilled really at the end of the quarter and therefore, having very little impact on fourth quarter volumes. A
componenttext: The rate for the fourth quarter? I think we just stick with what Steve said, which is we're kind of aiming towards a lot of those payouts getting tilled really at the end of the quarter and therefore, having very little impact on fourth quarter volumes. And so that results in the guidance being what it is. But we're -- we get asked a lot about response to current prices at any one point in time. And as Steve as alluded to, in this price environment, it doesn't seem like the right time to be going through any type of heroic efforts to get things turned online any more quickly, right? So if they -- the notion that was reflected in the guidance that those tills are going to drift backwards, it's just not troublesome. It still gets tilled. It just -- the question whether it's affect December volumes or January volumes is really the issue.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. And in the past, you're -- kind of brought up another question I have here. You guys actually talked about a pretty substantial kind of spread during the sales time of, call it, I think 9 months or so, and therefore, 2015 spending is really k
componenttext: Fair enough. And in the past, you're -- kind of brought up another question I have here. You guys actually talked about a pretty substantial kind of spread during the sales time of, call it, I think 9 months or so, and therefore, 2015 spending is really kind of baking in the 2016 growth rate. Given that, I mean, is that still in place imagine? Is there really a price at which in 2016, you would be able to really slow down the production? Or how do you tactically respond to gas prices in 2016 and if they continue to kind of remain at these levels on a realized base?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we look at that as 2016 plays out. Obviously, part of the consideration as you mentioned is what the prices are, but really the midstream is a big part of the consideration too. If you have some midstream flexibility, you can slow down and kind of m
componenttext: Well, we look at that as 2016 plays out. Obviously, part of the consideration as you mentioned is what the prices are, but really the midstream is a big part of the consideration too. If you have some midstream flexibility, you can slow down and kind of make it up later if you want to. And when the midstream is more full, then you have to decide, you either round it or you don't. And you want the volumes or you don't want to volumes because you can't really make it up on the back end, right. It's quite a ways down the road before you can make up those volumes. But we certainly take the prices into account when we're making our decisions about capital expenditures and what types of efforts to go through to try to accelerate or otherwise turn in line for wells.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then I guess, my one last one. On the gas processing side, do you have any increase, increases in commitments around volumes from gas processing? Contracts that we ought to be keeping in mind given how low prices?
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then I guess, my one last one. On the gas processing side, do you have any increase, increases in commitments around volumes from gas processing? Contracts that we ought to be keeping in mind given how low prices?

componenttext: And we'll go next to Stephen Richardson from Evercore.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: David, as you think about the strategy and [indiscernible] just went through some of the force thoughts of the Board, so is there any evolutionary thoughts in terms of what the right mix of upstream versus midstream capital is here in terms? And then appr
componenttext: David, as you think about the strategy and [indiscernible] just went through some of the force thoughts of the Board, so is there any evolutionary thoughts in terms of what the right mix of upstream versus midstream capital is here in terms? And then appreciate that EQM is funded, to some extent, organically. But in terms of returns and how to optimize that and beyond 2017, just considering the gas outlook versus the gathering outlook from right what you see from the different horizons here?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, first off, just to kind of to reiterate, my belief is, the further out in the future you look, the clearer, you mentioned beyond 2017, the clearer it is in my mind that capital expenditures for Midstream should be at the EQM level. We want to protec
componenttext: Well, first off, just to kind of to reiterate, my belief is, the further out in the future you look, the clearer, you mentioned beyond 2017, the clearer it is in my mind that capital expenditures for Midstream should be at the EQM level. We want to protect that IDR and the way to do that is to have the most attractive midstream projects possible. So if they can afford to pay the incremental cash flow to the GP, which is kind of a core value of that IDR where we stand now, so that's going to be the mines. It's strategically going to be midstream expenditure should occur at EQM. Now if you're trying to get it what's more available, generally midstream, upstream, I guess that's a bigger picture question than just 1 company, and we'll see. We're trying to position ourselves so we can be agnostic, so that we can take advantage of wherever the value is in the value chain. I agree that with the prospects of the Utica and issues like that, it's not clear what the value chain will look like several years down the road. But we think that the reason EQT is such an attractive investment is because EQT will participate no matter where the most value shows up in that value chain.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. And can you just remind us, as you think about upstream, like the right capital allocation at EQT production for next year and appreciating this 9 months or 12 months GAAP between when you deploy capital and when it shows up in production? Like wha
componenttext: Right. And can you just remind us, as you think about upstream, like the right capital allocation at EQT production for next year and appreciating this 9 months or 12 months GAAP between when you deploy capital and when it shows up in production? Like what is the -- is it a wellhead hurdle rate? Is it a corporate return? Is at a board burden return? What's the right...

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: We Look at all-in return, all-in after-tax returns is the way we tend to look at things. But that overlay that I mentioned in my prepared remarks was, we just think we need to bear in mind, what if the Deep Utica works and what does that mean for clearing
componenttext: We Look at all-in return, all-in after-tax returns is the way we tend to look at things. But that overlay that I mentioned in my prepared remarks was, we just think we need to bear in mind, what if the Deep Utica works and what does that mean for clearing prices, et cetera, and therefore, we should be particularly cautious about investing in anything but the core Marcellus, which does stand up still in that -- those environments and in the core Utica. So it's more of that. There's always uncertainty about what prices are going to be, but whenever you have a new low-cost supply source in any commodity business, you got to start being wearier of where one wants to invest one's money. So I think there's a certain amount of caution that we're taking that we're talking about because of that unknown, because not knowing yet the extent to which the Deep Utica will work. Feeling that if it works the way it's looking like it might, that the core areas for Marcellus and Utica are simply going to be narrower. And we're going to be able to supply a big portion of North America's natural gas needs from a relatively small geography.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. And -- sorry, just final question for me is, have you that -- maybe for Randy, in terms of conversations or thoughts on what the third-party opportunity is at this horizon? So again, we're all assuming that if this is economic and it is lower cost
componenttext: Right. And -- sorry, just final question for me is, have you that -- maybe for Randy, in terms of conversations or thoughts on what the third-party opportunity is at this horizon? So again, we're all assuming that if this is economic and it is lower cost and it isn't just some 0 game in terms of different capital going to the Utica, but is EQM particularly well positioned to capture a larger proportion of third -- potential third-party volumes in these areas than you have in the Marcellus? Is this a big piece of forward growth beyond $3 billion CapEx number?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think -- and this is Randy, I think we have a significant opportunity with the well results that we're seeing. In fact, I think Dave and Steve both mentioned that the core of the core Utica actually appears to sit on top of our EQM assets with the
componenttext: Well, I think -- and this is Randy, I think we have a significant opportunity with the well results that we're seeing. In fact, I think Dave and Steve both mentioned that the core of the core Utica actually appears to sit on top of our EQM assets with the Equitrans and the gathering assets along Jupiter and Northern West Virginia and our projects that we have embarked on currently, which is the Ohio Valley Connector and Mountain Valley Pipeline, I think positions us quite well to both -- move and be competitive and move gas for both affiliate as well as third parties. And so I think we're very competitive and well positioned.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, and to your point, probably we weren't as well positioned as you move a little bit outside of the core Marcellus from the midstream perspective. So this was emergence of the Utica is from a competitive and a comparative perspective, a positive for EQ
componenttext: Yes, and to your point, probably we weren't as well positioned as you move a little bit outside of the core Marcellus from the midstream perspective. So this was emergence of the Utica is from a competitive and a comparative perspective, a positive for EQM.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll go next to Drew Becker from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And we'll go next to Drew Becker from Morgan Stanley.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Could you speak to the 2015 [ph] program could change if we have a warm winter and gas prices are [indiscernible] I'm thinking about something around 2.25 [ph] for 2016. I'm particularly interested whether that was reduce your appetite to delineate the Ut
componenttext: Could you speak to the 2015 [ph] program could change if we have a warm winter and gas prices are [indiscernible] I'm thinking about something around 2.25 [ph] for 2016. I'm particularly interested whether that was reduce your appetite to delineate the Utica in 2016? I guess conversely, if prices are higher, would that change that Utica program at all?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: At that point though, you're just talking about what 2016 prices would be. I mean the norm in commodities, I understand, that does tend to be in the investor community a short-term focus. I recognize that people need to make money each quarter. But actual
componenttext: At that point though, you're just talking about what 2016 prices would be. I mean the norm in commodities, I understand, that does tend to be in the investor community a short-term focus. I recognize that people need to make money each quarter. But actually, lower prices near term tend to lead to more robust recoveries later. So our view is much more the low-cost opportunities are going to be the ones that went out and you want to make sure that you're, especially if you think prices are going to be stressed at all, that you're focusing on only going after the lowest cost opportunities and not like there's a kind of get drawn into investing in opportunities that are other than that. So I'd say, that's our focus anyway. And look, in the lower price environment, of course, we're talking about the Deep Utica for helping to create, that obviously becomes even more important.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. So I guess it sounds like there's probably not much change.
componenttext: Great. So I guess it sounds like there's probably not much change.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

componenttext: Well change, yes, but the thing is we're not telling what our 2016 plan is yet because we haven't got that approved from our board side. I'm not even sure how much telling you what the change would be versus the plan that we can't even discuss with you.

componenttext: Fair enough.

componenttext: If prices are lower, then we probably over time will spend less money. And if they're higher, we'll probably spend more money over time. But we already talking about 2016 been below fair bit below 2015 as it is.

componenttext: Right. Right. I was thinking, Dave, you mentioned maybe kind of 15 wells at the Utica in 2016 [ph]. That's really what I was thinking about, not the program.

Is it too early to think about that?

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, no. It's not too early to think about it, but we haven't actually settled down what that approach will be. Our bias is that a fair bit of the gathering for Utica is probably going to be severed because of the pressures involved. But as far as t
componenttext: Yes, well, no. It's not too early to think about it, but we haven't actually settled down what that approach will be. Our bias is that a fair bit of the gathering for Utica is probably going to be severed because of the pressures involved. But as far as the specifics and exactly where it is and exactly how much money it spent, that we haven't -- we're not ready to disclose that stuff. We're only just in the midst of even discussing that internally with our board.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: In the short term, we can put it in the Marcellus system. It's not the most optimum situation long term for the Utica because the gathering -- the Utica gathering cost for that Utica in a dedicated system will be significantly lower than the cost to move
componenttext: In the short term, we can put it in the Marcellus system. It's not the most optimum situation long term for the Utica because the gathering -- the Utica gathering cost for that Utica in a dedicated system will be significantly lower than the cost to move in through a Marcellus system. But for the next couple of years, until we figure out exactly what the optimum systems are and get them built, we can and they likely impact -- if we were doing that because the Utica was looking so good, we would probably be a shift from Marcellus investments to Utica, which is how -- which is where the capacity in those systems would effectively come from. We replace Marcellus gas with Utica and as we build Utica systems, at that point, we would start to get the benefits of the lower unit costs.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015

componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the EQT Corporation Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Patrick Kane, Chief Investor Relations Officer. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jennifer. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for participating in EQT Corporation's conference call. With me today are: Dave Porges, President and Chief Executive Officer; Phil Conti, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Randy Cra
componenttext:
Thanks, Jennifer. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for participating in EQT Corporation's conference call. With me today are: Dave Porges, President and Chief Executive Officer; Phil Conti, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Randy Crawford, Senior Vice President and President of Midstream & Commercial; and Steve Schlotterbeck, Executive Vice President and President of Exploration & Production.
This call will be replayed for a 7-day period beginning at approximately 1:30 today. The telephone number for the replay is (719) 457-0820. The confirmation code is 8682699. The call will also be replayed for 7 days on our website. To remind you, the results of the EQT Midstream Partners, ticker EQM, and EQ GP Holdings, ticker EQGP, are consolidated in EQT's results. Earlier this morning, there were a separate joint press release issued by EQM and EQGP. The partnership's conference call is at 11:30 a.m. today, which requires that we take the last question at 11:20. The dial-in number for that call is (913) 312-9034. The confirmation code is 2157781.
In just a moment, Phil will summarize EQT's results. Next, Steve will have a brief Utica update. Finally, Dave will provide preliminary thoughts on EQT's 2016 capital budget. Following their prepared remarks, Dave, Phil, Randy and Steve will be available to answer your questions.
I'd like to remind you that today's call may contain forward-looking statements. You can find factors that could cause the company's actual results to differ materially from these forward-looking statements listed in today's press release and under risk factors in EQT's Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2014, as updated by any subsequent Form 10-Qs, which are on file at the SEC and available on our website. Today's call may also contain certain non-GAAP financial measures. Please refer to this morning's press release for important disclosures regarding such financial measures, including reconciliations to the most comparable GAAP measure. 
Before turning the call over to Phil, I will walk you through one of the non-GAAP reconciliations that caused some confusion last quarter, specifically production adjusted net operating revenue presented on Page 7 of today's release. This number is used as the basis for calculating our average realized sales price as presented on the price reconciliation included in this morning's release. The average realized price is calculated by dividing the adjusted net operating revenue by total sales volumes. There is a non-GAAP reconciliation in the release that I will briefly explain. We are making 2 adjustments to EQT Production total operating revenues as reported on the segment page in order to provide you with operating revenues, excluding the noncash impact of derivatives and the net of transportation and processing costs. 
With respect to derivatives, adjustments for noncash derivative activity have been the subject of SEC comments over the past couple of years. As a result, in accordance with what appears to be the SEC preference in this area, we adjust out the noncash activity in 3 steps. First, we back out all gains and losses on derivatives not designated as hedges that were included in revenues during the period, which is the mark-to-market impact, which was 150 -- $160.5 million this quarter. Two, we add back the actual cash received, $33.2 million, and deduct the premiums paid for derivatives that settled during the quarter, which was $1 million, which leaves us with just the actual cash received net of any premiums made in our adjusted revenue number. The final adjustment on our non-GAAP reconciliation simply reduces the total operating revenues by $64.7 million of cost reported as expense on EQT Production segment page for transportation and processing. This provides a realized price net of transportation and processing costs, which is consistent with our historic presentation.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Phil Conti.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Pat, and good morning, everyone. As you read in the press release this morning, EQT announced the third quarter 2015 adjusted loss of $0.33 per diluted share, which represents an $0.83 per share decrease from adjusted EPS in the third quarter of '
componenttext:
Thanks, Pat, and good morning, everyone. As you read in the press release this morning, EQT announced the third quarter 2015 adjusted loss of $0.33 per diluted share, which represents an $0.83 per share decrease from adjusted EPS in the third quarter of '14. Adjusted operating cash flow was $156.3 million in the quarter or 46% lower than the third quarter of 2014. 
Results for the quarter were negatively impacted by lower commodity prices. Due to lower strip prices since last quarter, we also recorded a significant noncash gain on hedges of future production of $128.3 million during the quarter. And that was some of the stuff that Pat just talked about. And that's excluded from the adjusted earnings and cash flow.
I'd like to briefly take a look at our continuing and recently at EQGP. On October 20, 2015, EQGP announced a cash distribution to its unitholders of $0.104 per unit for the third quarter of '15 or a 13% increase over the equivalent full quarter distribution in the second quarter. The third quarter distribution decision represents $24.9 million in payments, which EQT will receive on November 23. These quarterly payments will continue to grow as distributions at EQGP grow and they highlight the value of EQGP to EQT.  
The operational results were fairly straightforward in the third quarter, so I'll move right into the segment results, and I will be brief. First, EQT Production continued to grow production sales volumes by 27% compared to the third quarter of 2014. However, revenues from that growth were more than offset by the lower commodity prices negatively impacting results in the third quarter. The average realized price at EQT Production was $1.21 per Mcf equivalent, a 55% decrease from $2.69 per Mcf equivalent last year, which led to adjusted operating revenues for the quarter of $188.5 million or $142.5 million lower than last year's third quarter.
There were many factors that led to the lower price, but lower NYMEX and liquids prices versus last year were the primary drivers. You will find the detailed components of the price differences in the tables in this morning's release. The adjusted operating loss at EQT Production was $72 million excluding the noncash gain on hedges of $128.3 million that I just mentioned. That compares to adjusted operating income of $107.9 million in the third quarter of '14. And that was also excluding a noncash gain on hedges.
Total operating expenses at EQT Production were $325.2 million or $53.5 million higher compared to the third quarter 2014. DD&A was $30.2 million higher. Transportation and processing expense was about $16 million higher. Exploration expense was $4.6 million higher. And LOE, excluding production taxes, was about $1.6 million higher, all consistent with the volume growth. Production tax decreased by $3 million due to lower commodity prices in the period. SG&A expense, excluding $3.5 million in rig release penalties, was about $0.5 million higher. 
Midstream results. Here, the operating income was up 21%. The increase is consistent with the growth of gathered volumes and increased fixed capacity-based transmission charges. Gathering revenues increased 23% to $125.9 million in the third quarter of '15 primarily due to a 24% increase in gathered volumes. Transmission revenues for the third quarter 2015 increased by $6.9 million or 12%, driven by additional firm-contracted capacity added over the past year. Operating expenses at midstream for the third quarter of $82.2 million were about $9.4 million higher than last year, consistent with the growth in the midstream business. 
And just to conclude with a brief note on liquidity. EQT did have $1.7 million of cash on hand at quarter-end, not including cash at EQM and EQGP as well as full availability under EQT's $1.5 billion credit facility. So we remain in a strong liquidity position to accomplish our goals for the foreseeable future. Our current estimate of 2015 EQT operating cash flow is $900 million, adjusted to exclude the noncontrolling interest portion of EQM and EQGP's cash flow. 
And with that, I'll turn the call over to Steve.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Phil. Today, I'll provide you an update on our deep Utica well program. As discussed on the last call, we completed our first deep Utica well in July, the Scotts Run 591340. To remind you, the well's initial 24-hour flow was 72.9 million cubic
componenttext:
Thank you, Phil. Today, I'll provide you an update on our deep Utica well program. As discussed on the last call, we completed our first deep Utica well in July, the Scotts Run 591340. To remind you, the well's initial 24-hour flow was 72.9 million cubic feet with an average flowing casing pressure of 8,641 psi. We've been flowing this well directly into the sales pipeline at a choke-restricted rate of about 30 million cubic feet per day. Except for the 7 days required to install the wellhead equipment, the oily sales have been steady at this rate. Casing pressure has been declining at an average of 40 psi per day. As of yesterday, sales volumes were 30.4 million cubic feet per day and the casing pressure was 6,320 psi.
Cumulative production from this well has totaled at 2.6 Bcf in the first 86 days of production. Our expectation is that the daily production rate will not decline until the well pressure declines through the pipeline pressure, which is 500 psi. Based on an extrapolation of the current pressure decline rate, we estimate that we'll reach line pressure after approximately 8 months of production, which will be in late March 2016. The cumulative production at that time would be approximately 7.4 Bcf. At that point, we have a wide range of possible decline curves as we do not have any analogous decline data to rely on. 
Our current reservoir modeling suggests an ultimate expected recovery for this well in a range between 13.9 Bcf and 18.8 Bcf or a range of 4.3 to 5.9 Bcf per thousand foot of lateral. Using the lowest EUR of our range and assuming the high end of our cost per well target of between $12.5 million and $14 million per well, we estimate returns at a $2 wellhead gas price to be north of 20% for a 5,400-foot lateral well.
Since the last call, we have spud 2 additional Utica wells. In August, we spud a second Greene County well, the Pettit #593066, which is located approximately 5 miles northeast of the Scotts Run well. We're currently at the depth of 12,200 feet and have installed the intermediate casing. We're just beginning to draw the curve on this well and expect this well to be in line before the end of the year.
The third well is spud in September in Wetzel County, West Virginia, the BIG-190 well, and is located approximately 30 miles southwest of the Scotts Run well. We reached TD as a deep intermediate hole. The top hole rig has been move off the well and the well is secured, awaiting the BIG rig to run the intermediate casing. The rest of the drilling will be completed when the Greene County rig is finished with the Pettit well and that rig is moved to West Virginia later this year.
We are making good progress on cost reductions for these wells. Specifically at the current depth of the Pettit well, we spent approximately 22% less than we did on the Scotts Run well at the same point. As I previously noted, we expect it to take several wells for us to achieve our cost target for these wells of between $12.5 million and $14 million. We are pleased with our progress so far and remain confident that we will achieve our targeted costs. We will continue to post well data from the Scotts Run well on our analyst presentation periodically, and we'll update you on the progress of the latest 2 wells as warranted.
I'll now turn the call over to David Porges for his initial thoughts on next year's capital budget.

headline: EQT Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve, and good morning, everyone. Today, the topic of my prepared remarks, as Steve mentioned, is our preliminary thinking regarding EQT's 2016 capital budget. We met with our board last week to discuss our long-term strategy as we do every Oc
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve, and good morning, everyone. Today, the topic of my prepared remarks, as Steve mentioned, is our preliminary thinking regarding EQT's 2016 capital budget. We met with our board last week to discuss our long-term strategy as we do every October. Our board then meets in early December to approve the upcoming year's operating plan and capital budget. 
A key aspect of the discussion in last week's meeting was the impact of the emerging deep Utica play on EQT's strategy. There have been fewer than 10 wells drilled and completed in the deep Utica around our acreage, so it is still too early to be confident that the play will be economic. But the early results are certainly encouraging. Specifically, if the Utica does work, which for us means that the returns are better than returns from the core Marcellus, we will certainly add significant resource potential to our inventory. However, the clearing price for natural gas will likely be lower in that scenario than if the Utica is less economic. 
As a result, some of our other inventory that requires high prices to make economic returns would be deferred possibly for many years. So while those of us, certainly including EQT, who have significant positions in the core of the deep Utica will be the winners, if you will, the cannibalization of other opportunities will affect everyone, including those of us who will net-net be much better off if the deep Utica play does work economically. 
Given this potential for lower long-term gas prices, we do not think it prudent to invest much money in wells whose all-in after-tax returns exceed our investment hurdle rates by only a relatively small amount. As a result, we are suspending drilling in those areas, such as Central Pennsylvania and our Upper Devonian play, that are outside that core. This decision will affect our 2016 capital plan, though we are just starting to develop the specifics of the 2016 drilling program that forms the core of that plan. The focus in 2016 will be on this more narrowly drawn notion of what the core Marcellus would be, assuming the deep Utica play works.
We will also pursue the deep Utica play with the goal of determining economics, size of resource and midstream needs and on lowering the cost per well to our target range. Our initial thoughts are a 10- to 15-well deep Utica program in 2016 with flexibility to shift capital between Marcellus and Utica as warranted based on our progress. 
Our preliminary estimate for production volume growth in 2016 versus 2015 is 15% to 20%, which we will refine when we announce our formal development plan on early December. If we turn in line our fourth quarter wells in late December, as contemplated in our fourth quarter guidance, 2016 growth would likely be near the upper end of that range as those wells would contribute little, if anything, to volumes until early 2016. Obviously, this overall approach will result in a 2016 capital budget, absent any acquisitions, that is a fair bit lower than 2015 and would result in continuing to have [indiscernible] of cash on hand as of end 2016. But we will provide specifics in December.
Another strategic implication of an economic deep Utica play is the significant opportunity for EQM. A year ago, it would be hard to imagine -- would've been hard to imagine a more prolific play than the Marcellus. And EQM has already announced a $3 billion backlog of midstream projects to serve the Marcellus play. Incidentally, that entire current backlog continues to make sense if the deep Utica proves economic as it either supports core Marcellus or take away projects that are needed regardless of the source rock for the natural gas.
However, if the deep Utica works, it is likely to be larger than the Marcellus over time. The magnitude of incremental takeaway in gathering pipeline such a play would support is significant, even net of the previously mentioned reduction to the Marcellus development that would occur in this scenario. As we think about the EQT corporate structure, we are not likely to make any major decisions to change the current integrated model until we do understand the scope of a potential deep Utica development program. We have reaped much value in recent years from having the 2 businesses together, and there is the potential that both companies would continue to benefit from these synergies into the dawn of the Utica era.
Finally, the deep Utica potential has also affected our thoughts around acreage acquisitions. Given our view that our existing acreage sits on what is expected to be the core of the core in deep Utica, we are focusing our interest -- our area of interest even more tightly on acreage that is in our core Marcellus and potentially core deep Utica area. As you can probably deduce from the lack of significant transaction announcements, the bid-ask spread continues to be wide. We are a patient company and believe that there will be acreage available at fair prices eventually. But the definition of fair has to contemplate the potential that the deep Utica works.
We do not think that bodes well for the price of acreage concentrated in anything but the core Marcellus and core Utica. This narrowing focus also suggests that smaller asset deals are much more likely than larger corporate deals. However, as we have stated previously, we are comfortable maintaining our industry-leading balance sheet even as we look for opportunities to create value.
In conclusion, EQT is committed to increasing the value of your shares. And we look forward to continuing to execute on our commitment to our shareholders and appreciate your continued support. With that, I will turn the call back over to Pat Kane.
